section.p: When you enter the Sessions menu, you have various options available for viewing the different session types. Select the type of session information you require. The options are:

li.p: Lists the total number of sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of Gx/IP-CAN sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of Rx/AF sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of Sy sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of Sd sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of PDU sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.
Lists the total number of Nchf sessions on the MEs according to the ME name.

section.p: After choosing the session type, you can double-click the ME name and view the session ID and Device ID.
When you double-click on the individual line items presented, you drill down to another level of detail about the line item you selected. For example, if you choose Session All, you will see:

li.p: the total number of sessions on the MEs and the aggregations of sessions on that ME as line items in the table;
Double-clicking on an ME name line, displays the following associated with the ME:

Double-clicking on one of the lines presented now, displays the detailed information associated with the ME, Session Id, and Device name as shown in the section “Viewing detailed session information”.

sectiondiv.p: The following table describes the parameters that are associated with each session type.

table.title: IP-CAN, AF, Sy, PDU, and Sd Session parameters

row.entry: Displays the hostname and realm that owns the session in the format: host.realm
A unique number that the server assigns to a user for the duration of session.
Displays the Date Time timestamp for the last update to the session.
Status of the CHF either true or false
The UE IP address that is requesting authentication or reauthentication of the user.
Contains the IPv6 prefix, if configured .
The Subscription ID contains the type and data used for the identity of the user.
The type of identifier that is carried by the subscription ID, for example, End User E.164, or End user IMSI.
The data available for the subscription identifier type that is used; for example, End User IMSI:310214000000001.
The type of connectivity access network to which the user is connected. For example, 3GPP EPS.
The RAT type that serves the UE. For example: EUTRAN.
Sent from the PCRF to the PCEF and indicates the PCRF selected bearer control mode. For example: UE_ONLY.
The UE and network support of the network-initiated requests. For example: NETWORK_REQUEST_NOT_SUPPORTED OR NETWORK_REQUEST_SUPPORTED
The device name as it is in the system.
The identifier of the Diameter peer.
An indication (either true or false) of whether the session is terminating.
Number of failed messages on this session.
The session id assigned to the user for the S9 session.
The concatenation of the S9 session ID and S9 sub-session ID.
The 3GPP RAT type that serves the UE (Release 8 GPRS or any non-GPRS access type).
Indicates the 'Time Zone' provided by the SGSN/MME.
Contains the trigger type registrations by rating group for Gy sessions.

entry.p: Displays whether or not QoS negotiation is supported. For example: QOS_NEGOTIATION_SUPPORTED.
This allows a single PCC rule request if the PCRF is allowed to negotiate the QoS by supplying an Authorized QoS that differs from the requested QoS.

row.entry: Contains the IPv4 address(es) of the access node gateway (SGW for 3GPP and AGW for non-3GPP networks).
Contains the IPv6 address(es) of the access node gateway (SGW for 3GPP and AGW for non-3GPP networks).
Identifies a request within a session. Used to indicate type of the requested action for event based scenarios.
Contains the trigger type registrations by rating group for Gx sessions.
Identifies the IPv4 address of the SGSN.
Identifies the IPv6 address of the SGSN.
The MCC-MNC of the SGW supports interoperator roaming scenario.
Contains the Routing Area Identity of the SGSN where the UE is registered.
An indication (either true or false) of whether the session is an emergency.
The IP address of the network entity within the access network that performs the charging function.
The IPv4 or IPv6 address for charging.

Contains a charging identifier (e.g. GCID) within the Access-Network-Charging-Identifier-Value AVP and the related PCC rule name(s) within the Charging-Rule-Name AVP(s) and/or within the Charging-Rule-Base-Name AVP(s).
A unique identifier and name for the Sy session.
Indicates details of where the UE is currently located (e.g. SAI or CGI).
Indicates whether the SGSN supports that the GGSN upgrades the QoS in a Create PDP context response or Update PDP context response. For example: QOS_UPGRADE_NOT_SUPPORTED
Contains the number of report registrations.
Indicates whether the default online charging method is enabled.
Indicates whether the default offline charging method is enabled.

The Revalidation-Time action, along with the Revalidation Time-out event trigger, is used to create a session for a finite period of time. In addition to sending the gateway the revalidation time, the NCC also initiates an internal revalidation timer.
S9 subsessions within an S9 session are created for each unique APN connection.
The time of the next scheduled reauthorization.
The time of the last reauthorization.
The time of the next rule status change.
Contains the character text string identifier of the NAS port that is authenticating the user.
Indicates the type of physical port the network access server (NAS) is using to authenticate the user.

Contains the identity of the logical access to which the user device is connected. It is stored temporarily in the AAA function connected to PDP. The identity can be the circuit-id from DHCPv4 Option 82,1 or interface-id from DHCPv6 option 18. The vendor-id is set to ETSI 13019. This corresponds to the Agent ID in case of IPv4 and to THR Interface Id of DHCP option 82 for IPv6.
Contains the identity of the physical access to which the user device is connected. It is stored temporarily in the AAA function connected to PDP. This corresponds to the Agent Remote ID.
Contains an IPv6 prefix that is delegated to the user. This attribute is usable within either RADIUS or Diameter.
Contains the revalidation time for IP-CAN sessions.

entry.p: Displays the QoS Class Identifier number for the default bearer.
The UE with IP connectivity for the duration of the PDN connection. This value can be changed using the QoS or SPR Update rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.

row.entry: The maximum amount of uplink bandwidth available for the APN
The maximum amount of downlink bandwidth available for the APN

entry.p: The relative importance of a resource request. The priority determines whether a bearer establishment or modification request can be accepted or needs to be rejected if resource are limited (typically used for the admission control of GBR traffic). The priority can also be used to determine the existing bearers to preempt during resource limitations.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.
Determines whether a service data flow can get resources that are already assigned to another service data flow with a lower priority level.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.
Determines whether a service data flow can lose the assigned resources in order to allow a service data flow with higher priority level.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.

row.entry: Contains the names of the active WNG policies.
The lower threshold value for the intensity of the WNG anomaly event. The range is 1 to 5.
Contains details of where the UE is currently located (for example, ECGI, SAI, TAI, or CGI).
Contains the Identity type (for example, ECGI, SAI, TAI, or CGI) and the data associated with the type.
Allows the credit-control client to indicate the identity and capability of the terminal that the subscriber is using for the connection to the network.
The type of UE information in the User-Equipment-Info-Value AVP. For example, IMEISV.
The value is the type of identifier that is used in the User-Equipment-Info-Value AVP.
The adjusted value for the session data.
The maximum amount of uplink bandwidth available for the APN
The maximum amount of downlink bandwidth available for the APN

The adjusted value for the UE with IP connectivity for the duration of the PDN connection. This value can be changed using the QoS or SPR Update rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.

entry.p: The adjusted value for the relative importance of a resource request. The priority determines whether a bearer establishment or modification request can be accepted or needs to be rejected if resource are limited (typically used for the admission control of GBR traffic). The priority can also be used to determine the existing bearers to preempt during resource limitations.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.
The adjusted value for the to determine whether a service data flow can get resources that are already assigned to another service data flow with a lower priority level.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.
The adjusted value for the to determine whether a service data flow can lose the assigned resources in order to allow a service data flow with higher priority level.
This value can be changed using the QoS, IP-CAN, and AF rule sets as appropriate with a rule that contains the Request-Type criteria.

row.entry: The maximum amount of bandwidth supported in the downlink direction.
The maximum amount of bandwidth supported in the uplink direction.
The data associated with the User Location ID.
The APN ID and active features.
Gives the Vendor ID, feature list ID, and feature list as supported.
The indentifier of the feature list AVP.
The feature List AVP is present.
The IP-CAN session to which the S9 is attached.
The UE IP address that is requesting authentication or reauthentication of the user. Displays the address family and value.
The PCC rule name, for example, in a 5G envirnment, the rule name is 5Gpcc
Whether the rule is active or not
Sent from the PCRF to the PCEF and indicates the PCRF selected bearer control mode. For example: UE_ONLY.
Guaranteed bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Guaranteed bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Maximum bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Maximum bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
APN AMBR value given in bits per second.
APN AMBR value given in bits per second.

The relative importance of a resource request. The priority determines whether a bearer establishment or modification request can be accepted or needs to be rejected if resource are limited (typically used for the admission control of GBR traffic). The priority can also be used to determine the existing bearers to preempt during resource limitations.
Determines whether a service data flow can get resources that are already assigned to another service data flow with a lower priority level.
Determines whether a service data flow can lose the assigned resources in order to allow a service data flow with higher priority level.
Guaranteed bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Guaranteed bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Maximum bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
Maximum bit rate with a value given in bits per second.
APN AMBR value given in bits per second.
APN AMBR value given in bits per second.

The relative importance of a resource request. The priority determines whether a bearer establishment or modification request can be accepted or needs to be rejected if resource are limited (typically used for the admission control of GBR traffic). The priority can also be used to determine the existing bearers to preempt during resource limitations.
Determines whether a service data flow can get resources that are already assigned to another service data flow with a lower priority level.
Determines whether a service data flow can lose the assigned resources in order to allow a service data flow with higher priority level.
The Vendor Specific Attributes associated with the NASREQ or IP-CAN session.

Indicates the interfaces that the PCRF supports for the authentication and authorization portion of the application. The value must be the same as the value in the AF-Application-Identifier AVP that is received during the AF creation of a PCC rule.

A unique four-octet value that is generated by the GGSN when a PDP context is activated. An ID is generated for each activated context. The charging ID of 0 is reserved and is not assigned by the GGSN.
Indicates the status of the service information that the AF provides to the PCRF.

entry.p: If both the Suppress ASR on CCR-T and RxRAR for PS to CS Handover Enabled application preferences are set to true, the ASR from the PCRF to the AF is suppressed.
If the ASR is not suppressed, which is the default value, the value field is blank.

When a CCR-U is received with PS to CS enabled, the Suppress ASR field has the value "PS to CS handover in progress". PS to CS handover in progress signifies that the PS_TO_CS_HANDOVER was reported in a CCR-U and the corresponding Rx-RAR was sent to the AF with Abort-Cause=PS_TO_CS_HANDOVER.

When the CCR-T is received, the message “ASR is suppressed during PS to CS handover” is displayed against the field. “ASR is suppressed during PS to CS handover” signifies that a CCR-T was received on the Gx and the corresponding Rx-ASR was suppressed.

row.entry: At the AA-Request level, provides the relative priority for a session while the Reservation-Priority at the Media-Component-Description level provides the relative priority for an IP flow in a session. If the Reservation-Priority AVP is not specified, the requested priority is DEFAULT (0).
Indicates that an AF Session is used for emergency traffic; for example, sos.fire.
Describes if several SIP dialogues are related to one Diameter session.
The identifier that indicates that an AF session relates to a Group Communication session that requires prioritization.
The identifier that indicates that an AF session relates to an MPS session. It contains the national variant for MPS service name.
An indication of whether the AF application has logged out.
An indication of whether the AF charging identifier has logged out.
Indicates the Billing account, account state, and active product offer.
Indicates the number of IP-CAN sessions.
Indicates the name of the Policy Counter Map for Gold Service.
Indicates the last SNR report state.
Indicates the last SNR report time.
